Award.AwardTitle: Independent effects of tropical forest fragmentation and habitat loss on hummingbird movement and pollination dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Most plant species depend on animals for successful reproduction. However, many plants and their associated pollinators are declining for reasons that are not well known. This project examines the extent to which pollen limitation is due to reduced movements of pollinators caused by landscape fragmentation and habitat loss. Since most pollinators are very small, the effects of habitat fragmentation on their movement has never before been tested. A large-scale experiment designed to disentangle the effects of tropical forest landscape connectivity, patch size, and habitat loss on plant pollination will test this idea. The study will be conducted in a tropical forest; this forest type is declining rapidly and plant-pollinator interactions in tropical forests is often highly specialized.

The project will capitalize on the charisma and diversity of tropical hummingbirds to transmit ideas about the importance of biodiversity conservation and ecosystem services to the general public. Results will be transferred to over 10,000 school children and undergraduates annually. School children in Oregon and Costa Rica will take part in a citizen-based monitoring effort to test whether landscape fragmentation affects hummingbirds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Though previous work has shown that habitat loss can reduce pollination, ours was one of the first studies to test whether landscape pattern (i.e., fragmentation per se) determines movement patterns of pollinators. If landscape fragmentation matters to pollinators, managers can design landscapes to mitigate the negative effects of habitat loss.

 

In particular, we sought to address the overall hypothesis that pollinator movement is altered by landscape fragmentation and that this can influence plant fitness (the ‘pollinator movement hypothesis’). We found that the movement of our focal pollinator species – the green hermit hummingbird (Phaethornis guy) – was strongly constrained by the effect of fragmentation; experimentally translocated hummingbirds selected connected forest corridors when moving through fragmented landscapes. Green hermit hummingbirds also tend to avoid crossing gaps in their daily movement and have reduced home range sizes in fragmented landscapes, which limits their capacity to transport long-distance, high-quality pollen (i.e., pollen from non-relatives). Reduced abundance of hummingbirds in fragments suggests that this movement limitation may be widespread across species within the pollinator community. This disruption to hummingbird movement has severe demographic consequences for Heliconia tortuosa. Seed set of this species was reduced by more than 50% in tropical forest fragments relative to continuous forest, and was strongly positively correlated with the abundance of traplining hummingbird species across a fragmentation gradient. As a result, the density of H. tortuosa seedlings has declined in fragmented patches by a factor of ~3x across the range of fragments we observed. Finally, corridors between forest fragments not only facilitate hummingbird movement, but also increase the fitness of H. tortuosa.

 

Our work uncovered a critical knowledge gap from previous studies that have considered pollination as a function of landscape structure; the effects of habitat loss have not been distinguished from those of habitat fragmentation. This means that managers seeking to plan landscapes to maximize pollination services have little science to inform these decisions (e.g., whether patches should be a certain size or configuration vs. simply maintaining the maximum amount of habitat). Our work developed recommendations for future studies in landscape pollination ecology that we hope will assist in the development of the field. In our empirical work, we are one of <5 studies worldwide to test directly for 'fragmentation' effects on pollination. Our mensurative experiment revealed that patch size, a configuration variable, has strong effect on pollination success, though the strength of this effect appears to vary among years. This finding has implications for reserve design and land-use planning for pollination.

 

We trained five graduate students and seven undergraduates through this project and developed an extensive outreach program for k-12 students. This work has already resulted in 12 peer reviewed publications that have garnered substantial media attention.
